> [ks](#comment_37_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): One question: how will you do the authentication with NMC?

New Local ZeroID will handle that! It will do smth like what NXT is doing or just generate some other stuff, the only thing what NMC is needed here for is to store a name and to tell NLZeroID that it really has that name!

Because NLZeroID will be opensource, anyone will be able to check if it's not doing anything wrong! (And ofcource it will have some special way to encode the data so that site would be able to check that this plugin is a real ZeroID, not some fork that just says "I HAVE ALL NAMES!"
But now I'm not so sure what's easier: to adopt NXT or to adopt NMC for auth purposes xD

> [ks](#comment_39_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): Oh, and another thing: When you authenticate with NXT you don't use the blockchain at all, so there's no waiting time and no fees. It's like an OTP generator.

YES, what I'm saying is that someone can write such a generator for NMC as a ZeroNet plugin!!
Don't you think that's possible???

> [ks](#comment_39_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): Oh, and another thing: When you authenticate with NXT you don't use the blockchain at all, so there's no waiting time and no fees. It's like an OTP generator.

It's just that I don't like that NXT stores Aliases "forever", That sucks. That means that sooner or later it will be too crowded and ppl will just choose smth else...

On the other hand, why is that so? NXT is a platform, anyone can fork "Aliases" and just make "Aliases 2" for his own network. Right?

What do you think?

> [wrewolf](#comment_1_18iELxgQf2hpjFuBofjEJyuvVazJt2ekSp): why not: git clone ... ?

sorry, was not around here for a while. because it's a horror to type in commands on a tablet sometimes. And it's not possible to copy into a terminal from some browsers, so I've decided to make it this way. Sure no one stops you from using git clone.

Ah, yes, also because git is not installed there and it's faster to dl a file with a normal browser instead of installing/removing git in a tablet's terminal =D

> [wrewolf](#comment_2_18iELxgQf2hpjFuBofjEJyuvVazJt2ekSp): Awesome, but don't forget to stop ZM before switch to mobile network ;)

No need. It's not eating much. But I need to correct my battery reports - it does consume more due to constand sending/receiving. So yes it's a good idea to switch the connection off when you don't need it or pause all sites/ close the app when you don't need them. I've asked nofish for a "pause all" button, but not sure my message got away. I did that from an underground train. Connection to mobile network sucks there.

> i wanted to show you the link between a zeronet site and an ipfs site, have you noticed that?

Yes, sure. But you are late here too. I used to have a post in this blog called "another way to use IPFS". There was a link that led to IPFS site. On that site there was my pingpong game. But I have decided to move the game to ZN (look My Sites -> Ping Pong), so that if I want to change anything, it will be easier to share (just press "sign"). Plus on ZN I can track how many ppl have my site and on IPFS all I have is my hope xD
agree with both comments, however I'm not so fond of autarchy.

> [erkan](#comment_16_1H8oKiRa7fGgUqS1hpUtaSYLvAqkaknbkf): Which aspects ?

I don't say I don't like it. Just said I don't think it's so cool =)

It's not a problem to run ZN and IPFS for me, so I don't need autarchy here.

_____________________
Servers were autarchy. Dependant only on power provided by companies. Buy a generator and enough oil and you have an absolute self-sufficiency. Distributed web is a movement against it. To community of people where everyone is both dependant and independant at the same time. It is built in a way to provide autarchy for each componet in the web, but the web itself is dependant on every single one of the components.

What I see when I look at ZN, IPFS and Namecoin (as they are now) - the community of apps.

you have to bind ZN to Local Network instead of Local Host. (127.0.0.1 -> 192.168.1.1). Then you can access it from local network. The problem is: anyone can. And anyone can use your sites this way. You have to find a way to setup multiuser access and make accounts. I had no need for that because I simply installed ZNet everywhere I could.

> [pycole](#comment_6_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): Alright then. I can sympathize a bit--my ratio only ever get over 0 when I leave i2p on for awhile--like, days. Only on rare occasion does the ratio break even.

> [ks](#comment_73_14TDWFVHuTXNcg8pp6LRr7v9ZcfbFsMSyx): I enjoyed reading the Ender Saga (all of the books). However, watching Ender's Game was a big disappointment: while the cinematography was ok, the plot was pruned / altered unacceptably.

I disagree. The movie has disappointed me somewhat, but the reason for that feeling was that it is impossible to compress Ender's Game in 2 hours. I have realised that when I thought "man! they skip a scene after scene and all they show is as if playing in "fast froward"! 15 minutes passed and Ender is already a commander! What's wrong with those guys?!" Then I've checked a play time and a counter was showing about an hour. So even with such a great speed of event-shift, the movie is quite big. Movie makers did what they could and the result is not bad. Children act pretty well there.

Watch the movie again (if you have a couple of hours), but take in consideration the fact that main actors there are children (lots of them), and that film DOES show all main moments from the book in only 2 hours.

And if they had decided to make the film larger (3 hours?), MAYBE they could make a film a little more like the book, but then it would require several more weeks to make it. Think what would that do to children!

Simplifactions **were** required. And result isn't BAD.

> [mynameislegion](#comment_1_1NAaF8VitwKSPo79RzJFhqz14gndmdWcGV): So whenever you open a new virtual machine, you'll have to install the OS from scratch? It is basically like using virtualbox?

nope. Please read about the OS from their site - that way you won't be misguided by me.

Qubes has several types of VMs:
- AdminVM - Desktop with a very limited access;
- TemplateVM - OS root. Debian and Fedora are installed with 1 command in a terminal. Others are a trouble usually (as far as I see).
- AppVM - home folder with apps and read-only access to root. This way you can make many VMs fast and to be able to update them all at once.
- other VMs. Don't have time to write now, and I have answered your question. For more info, read Qubes OS [documentation (ClNet!)](data/users/content.json).
thanks
